====Greece====
====Greece====
  +
[[File:2011 Greece Uprising.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators in front of the Greek parliament, 29 May.]]
{{main|2010-2011 Greek protests}}
{{main|2010-2011 Greek protests}}
The impact of the Arab Spring and the [[2011 Spanish protests]] was a major source of influence for the latest wave of anti-government protests in [[Greece]].<ref name="Euronews Greece">{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/05/25/outraged-greek-youth-follow-spanish-example/ |title=Outraged Greek youth follow Spanish example |date=25 May 2011 |publisher=www.euronews.eu |accessdate=30 May 2011 |quote=First the Arab world, then Madrid, now Athens. Outraged Greek youth has taken its lead from the Arab spring and Spanish protests over unemployment.}}</ref><ref name="BBC Greek Revolution">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13830466 |title=Greece crisis: Revolution in the offing? |date=19 June 2011 |publisher=www.bbc.co.uk |accessdate=20 June 2011 |quote=Inspired by the Arab uprisings, they have dug in to oppose further spending cuts in exchange for a second bail-out by the EU and IMF.}}</ref> The Greek protests were organized over the internet, and the focal point of the demonstrations is [[Athens]]' [[Syntagma Square|Syntagma]] (or Constitution) Square. The '''Indignant Citizens Movement''' has been holding protests in Athens and over 30 other Greek cities since May 25, 2011,<ref name="Euronews Greece" /> with 30,000 attending the first demonstration in Athens on the first day.<ref name="Euronews Greece" /> The most massive demonstration was on June 5, and some estimates put the number of protesters in front of the Greek parliament to over 300,000, while low estimates place the number to well over 100,000.<ref name="Skai 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171405/deutero-kalesma-europaikou-xesikomou/ |title=ÎÎµÏÏÎµÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ¬Î»ÎµÏÎ¼Î± ÎµÏÏÏÏÎ±ÏÎºÎ¿Ï Î¾ÎµÏÎ·ÎºÏÎ¼Î¿Ï |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Eleftherotypia 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=281844 |title=ÎÎºÎºÏÏÎ±Î½ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ® Î»Î±Î¿Î¸Î¬Î»Î±ÏÏÎ± ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Proto Thema 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=126165 |title=300.000 ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ ÏÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÎ¿ ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î±Ï! |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref>
The impact of the Arab Spring and the [[2011 Spanish protests]] was a major source of influence for the latest wave of anti-government protests in [[Greece]].<ref name="Euronews Greece">{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/05/25/outraged-greek-youth-follow-spanish-example/ |title=Outraged Greek youth follow Spanish example |date=25 May 2011 |publisher=www.euronews.eu |accessdate=30 May 2011 |quote=First the Arab world, then Madrid, now Athens. Outraged Greek youth has taken its lead from the Arab spring and Spanish protests over unemployment.}}</ref><ref name="BBC Greek Revolution">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13830466 |title=Greece crisis: Revolution in the offing? |date=19 June 2011 |publisher=www.bbc.co.uk |accessdate=20 June 2011 |quote=Inspired by the Arab uprisings, they have dug in to oppose further spending cuts in exchange for a second bail-out by the EU and IMF.}}</ref> The Greek protests were organized over the internet, and the focal point of the demonstrations is [[Athens]]' [[Syntagma Square|Syntagma]] (or Constitution) Square. The '''Indignant Citizens Movement''' has been holding protests in Athens and over 30 other Greek cities since May 25, 2011,<ref name="Euronews Greece" /> with 30,000 attending the first demonstration in Athens on the first day.<ref name="Euronews Greece" /> The most massive demonstration was on June 5, and some estimates put the number of protesters in front of the Greek parliament to over 300,000, while low estimates place the number to well over 100,000.<ref name="Skai 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.skai.gr/news/greece/article/171405/deutero-kalesma-europaikou-xesikomou/ |title=ÎÎµÏÏÎµÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ¬Î»ÎµÏÎ¼Î± ÎµÏÏÏÏÎ±ÏÎºÎ¿Ï Î¾ÎµÏÎ·ÎºÏÎ¼Î¿Ï |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Eleftherotypia 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.enet.gr/?i=news.el.ellada&id=281844 |title=ÎÎºÎºÏÏÎ±Î½ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ® Î»Î±Î¿Î¸Î¬Î»Î±ÏÏÎ± ÏÏÎ¿ Î£ÏÎ½ÏÎ±Î³Î¼Î± |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.enet.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Proto Thema 5">{{cite web |url=http://www.protothema.gr/greece/article/?aid=126165 |title=300.000 ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎµÏ ÏÏÎ¿ ÎºÎ­Î½ÏÏÎ¿ ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ¸Î®Î½Î±Ï! |language=Greek |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=www.skai.gr |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref>
The reasons for the demonstrations across Greece were the harsh austerity measures the country was forced to take as part of an [[IMF]]-[[EU]] bailout plan in 2010 that were ineffective, the people's belief that the politicians are corrupt and do not serve the people but international interests, the country's continuously renewed two-party system, high numbers of unemployment, especially for the youth, the government's proposal for new austerity measures, the presence of the [[International Monetary Fund]] in the country, and others.<ref name="Real Democracy Now! demands">{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/el/%CF%83%CF%84%CF%8C%CF%87%CE%BF%CE%B9-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%BA%CE%B9%CE%BD%CE%AE%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82%CF%83%CF%85%CE%B6%CE%B7%CF%84%CE%AE%CF%83%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82 |title=Î£ÏÏÏÎ¿Î¹ ÏÎ¿Ï ÎºÎ¹Î½Î®Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï/Î£ÏÎ¶Î·ÏÎ®ÏÎµÎ¹Ï |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.real-democracy.gr |accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref>
The reasons for the demonstrations across Greece were the harsh austerity measures the country was forced to take as part of an [[IMF]]-[[EU]] bailout plan in 2010 that were ineffective, the people's belief that the politicians are corrupt and do not serve the people but international interests, the country's continuously renewed two-party system, high numbers of unemployment, especially for the youth, the government's proposal for new austerity measures, the presence of the [[International Monetary Fund]] in the country, and others.<ref name="Real Democracy Now! demands">{{cite web |url=http://real-democracy.gr/el/%CF%83%CF%84%CF%8C%CF%87%CE%BF%CE%B9-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%BA%CE%B9%CE%BD%CE%AE%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82%CF%83%CF%85%CE%B6%CE%B7%CF%84%CE%AE%CF%83%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82 |title=Î£ÏÏÏÎ¿Î¹ ÏÎ¿Ï ÎºÎ¹Î½Î®Î¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï/Î£ÏÎ¶Î·ÏÎ®ÏÎµÎ¹Ï |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=www.real-democracy.gr |accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref>
